dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARK KENT comes in, ready to begin a day's work, chipper As a REPORTER with a sheaf of wire service copy in hand b CLARK Morning, Phil --- PHIL (can't stop to talk) 'Scuse me Kent.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark is a bit surprised, but continues walking on. A WOM CLARK (cheerily) Hi, Alice. That's a very pretty  blouse you - ALICE (preoccupied) Catch you later, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: STAY WITH CLARK, now a bit taken aback, as he reaches Per

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (one more try)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy, how's the -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (to telephone) Yeah. I'll check. He hangs up and goes to Perry' s office.  Clark follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERRY WHITE is seated at his desk, looking even more woun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. White, the pressroom wants to know how

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: much longer to hold the front page.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: Give it another ten minutes. If we don't -- (changing his mind) Hell, I'll tell him. (he picks up a phone) Pete? If we haven't got anything new in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: next ten minutes just go with the wire service copy under the 40 pt. banner and run the  picture for three columns. (to Clark) Kent,        I need a background story for the page 3 sidebar. Give me every thing you know about this terrorist group.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (automatic response) Right! (he turns, starts out briskly,  then stops, turns and looks at Perry with a puzzle expression) What terrorists group? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: Get your head out of the clouds, Kent. Where  you been  the last twelve hours?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Uh...home...

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: Don't you watch television? Don't you listen to the radio?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Actually I was trying to catch up on my  reading. There's a lot of Dickens I never got  around to --

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: Dickens! The whole world's about to blow up and you're reading Dickens?!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (explaining to the  confused Clark) A gang of terrorists seized the Eiffel Tower in Paris

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: He knows where the Eiffel Tower is, Olsen. (double checking) You do, don't you, Kent?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Anybody been hurt?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: So far the hostages are unharmed.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Hostages?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Tourists, about twenty of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: But that's penny-ante        stuff. These guys

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are saying that unless the French government meets their demand they've got a hydrogen   bomb ready to level Paris. C.U. CLARK shocked. CLARK But . . ..that's terrible!

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: That's why they call 'em terrorists. (brusquely)         Go down to the morgue and dig up anything you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: can find on past incidents of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sudden thought) Does Lois know about this yet?

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: Does she know about it? She's in it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minute the story broke I bundled her on the first

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concord out of here. If Paris goes kablooey I want the  best reporter I've got right there in the middle of it. FAVORING CLARK-- He looks especially worried now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee. But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, Kent. You're good, but Lois is the best

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we've got.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: No, I meant, it's awfully dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: That goes with the territory, Kent. (cheering him up) Listen, if I know Lois Lane, she'll not only come back with a Pulitzer Prize story, she'll have a one  on one interview with the hydrogen bomb titled  "What Makes Me Tick. " ON CLARK -- He stands there, absorbed in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: What are you standing around for, Kent? Come on! Take off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark comes swiftly out  of the building. PAN TO SEE him behind it.

dialogues.text: WIDE        SHOT,         SIDE ANGLE - In this private pl transforms into Superman. dialogues.text: FIRST REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (British accent) How did they get up there?

dialogues.speaker: SPOKESMAN
dialogues.text: (French accent) They were disguised as workers, to do repairs.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST REPORTER
dialogues.text: Can you tell us why they released the first group  of hostages?

dialogues.speaker: SPOKESMAN
dialogues.text: We insist they do this to show good faith. If not,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we refuse to negotiate.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: (American accent) And now they are willing to release the rest of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hostages?

dialogues.speaker: SPOKESMAN
dialogues.text: In return for a guarantee that we will not launch an  attack an them.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: There will be no attack? No attempt to overpower the  terrorists?

dialogues.speaker: SPOKESMAN
dialogues.text: (squirming a bit ) Um. . . .we have made this guarantee.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: Yes, but will you honor it?

dialogues.speaker: SPOKESMAN
dialogues.text: We have not the choice to refuse, have we, if we believe  it is a real hydrogen bomb that they have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the bomb ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is in a big oil can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: But . . ..that would mean all of Paris would be destroyed

dialogues.speaker: SPOKESMAN
dialogues.text: (grimly) Oui.

dialogues.text: Standing patiently beside the desk with a long-suffering LOIS Look, okay, this time you were lucky. Very lucky. But next time you cross the street -- (earnestly) Clark, always look both ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lecture over, she starts rummaging in the shopping bag we CLARK (equally earnest) Lois, I usually do. LOIS Then maybe you should get your glasses checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he touches them nervously, she pulls out a plastic bag CLARK (piqued) Not everyone can have X-ray vision, you know. LOIS (lightly) Do I detect a note of jealousy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the bottom of bag she produces a fairly ancient hand

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLARK (looking at all this with much curiosity) Lois, what are you doing? LOIS When was the last time you heard me  sneeze? CLARK (actually trying to remember) Uh. . .  LOIS Well, you never will again! (proselytizing) Thanks to Vitamin C! I'm reading a book that says the foundation of a sound body structure is one thousand milligrams of Vitamin C every day. CLARK One thousand?? That's an awful lot of oranges. You know there are pill, Lois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen them.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Oh sure. The American answer to everything. Pills. (as she puts an orange in the juicer) No, this is -- (the magic word) -- natural. She brings up the lever and bears down on the orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I also get some exercise this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for sure. Struggling mightily, she can hardly get brightly as this doesn't bother her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LOIS Anyway, about being jealous -- you don't have to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's about to give it another try. CLARK I don't? LOIS (smiling at him) Of course not. Not when you've got so much going for you. CLARK (daring to hope) I do? LOIS Sure! But nobody knows it. Least of all you. (as his smile fades) Look, would you mind if I gave you  some constructive criticism? CLARK (hurting) Actually, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOIS Well, you shouldn't (intensely) Be more aggressive, Clark! Trust your instinct! When you see your opportunity, grab it! I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she pushes down the lever. CLARK God knows . . .

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is really having a tough time getting the press to go CLARK Lois, why don't you at least get one of those automatic ones? LOIS Haven't you heard? There's an energy crisis. (through clenched teeth: as she bears down) No, this was good enough for my mother -- CLARK (tentatively) Maybe I could try -- LOIS Be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He repositions the orange and raises the lever. Clumsily, pains, orange pulp juice spattered down the front of his unperturbed. CLARK (mopping himself) It's okay, I was going to send this suit to the cleaners anyway. (he puts another orange  in the juicer) I think I've got the hang of this now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE - He brings the lever down, then tosses away th can't see what he's accomplished yet.  LOIS (kindly) Clark, everything I was saying -- can't you  see I only say it because I really care? CLARK (looking up, a last ray of hope) Really? LOIS Of course, that's what friends are for.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
